guidelines.label: Heart Failure (ACC/AHA/HFSA)
guidelines.source: 2022 AHA/ACC/HFSA Guideline for the Management of Heart Failure

recommendations.text: In patients with HFrEF, guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT) that includes an ACE inhibitor, ARB, or ARNI; a beta-blocker; an MRA; and an SGLT2 inhibitor is recommended to reduce morbidity and mortality.
In patients with HFrEF, ACE inhibitors are recommended to reduce morbidity and mortality.
In patients with chronic HFrEF, beta-blockers (bisoprolol, carvedilol, or metoprolol succinate) are recommended to reduce morbidity and mortality.
In patients with HFrEF (NYHA class II–IV) who remain symptomatic, an MRA is recommended to reduce morbidity and mortality.
In patients with HFrEF, SGLT2 inhibitors are recommended to reduce hospitalization and mortality.
Treatment of hypertension is recommended in patients with Stage A heart failure (at risk) to prevent development of HF.
In patients with HF and fluid overload, diuretics are recommended to improve symptoms.
In patients with HFrEF who are candidates for an ICD, ICD therapy is recommended for primary prevention of sudden cardiac death.
Multidisciplinary heart failure disease-management programs are recommended for patients with HF to reduce hospitalization and mortality.
In patients with HF, vaccination against influenza and pneumococcal disease is recommended.

guidelines.label: Diabetes (ADA)
guidelines.source: American Diabetes Association Standards of Medical Care in Diabetes

recommendations.text: At least annual screening for diabetic kidney disease by estimating glomerular filtration rate and urinary albumin excretion is recommended for all patients with type 2 diabetes.
Metformin is the preferred initial pharmacologic agent for the treatment of type 2 diabetes.
For patients with type 2 diabetes and established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, an SGLT2 inhibitor or GLP-1 receptor agonist with demonstrated cardiovascular benefit is recommended.
In adults with overweight or obesity and type 2 diabetes, intensive lifestyle intervention that includes calorie restriction and increased physical activity is recommended to promote weight loss.
For patients with type 2 diabetes and diabetic kidney disease, an SGLT2 inhibitor with evidence of reducing kidney disease progression is recommended.
Blood pressure should be measured at every routine clinical visit. Patients with blood pressure ≥140/90 mmHg should have blood pressure confirmed on a separate day.
For patients with diabetes and hypertension, either an ACE inhibitor or an ARB is recommended for those with modestly elevated urinary albumin-to-creatinine ratio.
All patients with diabetes should be screened for distal symmetric polyneuropathy at diagnosis and at least annually thereafter.
Adults with type 1 or type 2 diabetes should be screened for diabetic retinopathy at diagnosis and at least annually thereafter.
Glycemic targets should be individualized; for many nonpregnant adults, an A1C goal of <7% is appropriate.

guidelines.label: Hypertension (ACC/AHA)
guidelines.source: 2017 ACC/AHA Guideline for the Prevention, Detection, Evaluation, and Management of High Blood Pressure

recommendations.text: Adults with hypertension should be treated to a blood pressure goal of <130/80 mm Hg.
Nonpharmacologic interventions including weight loss, DASH diet, sodium reduction, and increased physical activity are recommended for adults with elevated BP or hypertension.
First-line antihypertensive agents include ACE inhibitors, ARBs, calcium channel blockers, and thiazide diuretics.
In black adults with hypertension, initial antihypertensive treatment should include a thiazide diuretic or CCB.
In adults with hypertension and chronic kidney disease, ACE inhibitors or ARBs are recommended.
Blood pressure should be measured in the office with proper technique; out-of-office BP measurement is recommended to confirm the diagnosis of hypertension.
In adults with hypertension and diabetes, target BP is <130/80 mm Hg.
In adults with hypertension and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, ACE inhibitors (or ARB or ARNI), beta-blockers, and MRAs are recommended.
Lifestyle modification is recommended for all adults with elevated BP or hypertension.
Resistant hypertension is defined as BP that remains above goal despite concurrent use of 3 antihypertensive agents of different classes.

guidelines.label: Atrial Fibrillation (ACC/AHA/HRS)
guidelines.source: 2019 AHA/ACC/HRS Focused Update of the 2014 Guideline for the Management of Atrial Fibrillation

recommendations.text: Anticoagulation with warfarin or a DOAC is recommended in patients with AF and CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or greater in men or 3 or greater in women.
In patients with AF and mechanical heart valves, warfarin is recommended.
Rate control with a beta-blocker or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker is recommended for symptomatic management in patients with AF.
In patients with AF and hemodynamic instability, immediate cardioversion is recommended.
In patients with AF of more than 48 hours or of unknown duration, anticoagulation for at least 3 weeks before and 4 weeks after cardioversion is recommended.
Assessment of thromboembolic risk with CHA2DS2-VASc and bleeding risk with HAS-BLED is recommended for all patients with AF.
In patients with AF and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, a beta-blocker is recommended for rate control.
Catheter ablation of AF is recommended in symptomatic patients with refractory AF who have failed antiarrhythmic drug therapy.
In patients with AF, treatment of contributing factors such as hypertension, obesity, and sleep apnea is recommended.
DOACs are preferred over warfarin for most patients with nonvalvular AF, except in those with moderate to severe mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves.

guidelines.label: Pneumonia (IDSA/ATS)
guidelines.source: IDSA/ATS Consensus Guidelines on the Management of Community-Acquired Pneumonia

recommendations.text: For outpatients with CAP and no comorbidities, amoxicillin or doxycycline is recommended.
For outpatients with CAP and comorbidities, a respiratory fluoroquinolone or beta-lactam plus macrolide is recommended.
For inpatients with nonsevere CAP, a beta-lactam plus macrolide or a respiratory fluoroquinolone is recommended.
For inpatients with severe CAP, a beta-lactam plus either a fluoroquinolone or macrolide is recommended.
Blood cultures are recommended for adults with severe CAP before antibiotic therapy.
Pneumococcal urinary antigen testing is recommended for adults with severe CAP.
Legionella urinary antigen testing is recommended for adults with severe CAP.
Antibiotic therapy should be initiated as soon as possible after diagnosis of CAP.
For CAP caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus, vancomycin or linezolid is recommended.
Influenza vaccination is recommended annually for all persons aged 6 months and older to prevent influenza and influenza-associated CAP.
